CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Mykhaylo Buromenskiy;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . DATE the Bila Tserkva Tax Police ( “ the police ” ) instituted and subsequently discontinued several sets of criminal proceedings against the applicant for property embezzlement and tax evasion .
CARDINAL . On DATE he claimed compensation from the police for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage in respect of the above proceedings .

CARDINAL . By a letter of DATE the police informed the applicant that his claims had to be rejected as unsubstantiated . They noted that he had been found guilty and amnestied in CARDINAL set of the proceedings and that the property which had been seized from him in the course of the proceedings had in fact remained in his possession .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant repeated his claim , which remained without reply .

CARDINAL . On DATE he brought proceedings before the ORG ( “ the FAC ” ) against the police , claiming compensation for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage in respect of the criminal proceedings against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court stayed the examination of his claim in the part concerning the pecuniary damage having indicated some shortcomings which had to be rectified by DATE . It referred to section CARDINAL of the Act “ On the procedure of compensation for damage caused to citizens by unlawful actions of bodies of inquiry , pre - trial investigation authorities , prosecutors and courts ” ( “ the LAW ” ) , according to which the amount of compensation for pecuniary damage was to be established by a resolution of the respective authority ( the police in the present case ) . The court noted that the police had rejected the applicant 's claim for such compensation by their letter of DATE and that the applicant had not introduced a judicial appeal against that refusal . As to his claim in the part concerning the non - pecuniary damage , it was subsequently examined by the domestic courts and rejected as unsubstantiated .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the applicant introduced a complaint , by which he challenged the refusal of his claim by the police . Referring to his CARDINAL requests to them of DATE and DATE , he argued that he had made every attempt to settle the issue before bringing the judicial action .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court rejected the above claim as time - barred , referring to the fact that the applicant had failed to raise it within DATE after he had become aware of the discontinuation of the criminal proceedings against him ( DATE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the Court of Appeal ” ) quashed the above decision on the applicant 's appeal and remitted the case for fresh examination . It noted that the first - instance court had wrongly considered that the applicant 's claim concerned the criminal proceedings against him . Instead , it should have been deemed to concern the refusal of the police to award him compensation for pecuniary damage . It further noted in that connection that the first - instance court had failed to clarify whether the police had issued a resolution concerning the applicant 's compensation claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to consider the applicant 's complaint , since no resolution in that respect had been issued by the police in accordance with section CARDINAL of LAW . The court also relied on the fourth paragraph of LAW in the part compliant with LAW pursuant to the decision of ORG of DATE . It considered that it had no jurisdiction over the case , as the aforementioned provision provided for “ a different procedure for lodging claims ” , namely through challenging a resolution of the police . Accordingly , the court instructed the applicant that he could apply to the tax police “ for settling the compensation issue under the legally envisaged procedure ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , submitting that the first - instance court had been unduly formalistic as the police had clearly stated their position in the letter of DATE . He further argued that he could not be held responsible for the inadequate form of the response to his claim .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the finding of ORG that given the absence of a resolution there was no procedural basis for the judicial examination of the applicant 's claim .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE rejected the applicant 's cassation appeal as unsubstantiated .

CARDINAL . The relevant constitutional provisions , as well as references to the pertinent practice of ORG and ORG , can be found in GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , DATE and DATE , DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW are cited in the partial admissibility decision of DATE concerning this application .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure DATE ( as worded at the material time ) read as follows :
“ The following complaints shall be outside the courts ' jurisdiction :

- ... against actions or acts of an official of a body of inquiry , preliminary investigation , prosecution or court with regard to which a different procedure for lodging claims is established .... ”

By decision of ORG . CARDINAL of DATE this provision was declared unconstitutional in the part concerning lack of the courts ' jurisdiction to examine complaints “ against actions or acts of an official of a body of inquiry , preliminary investigation , prosecution ... ” , where the legislation provided only for extrajudicial settlement .
